#8
Nanking, November 8, 1937.
Dear
Family:
Today
was bright and clear - not a cloud in the sky.
a passenger
train north of here killing two hundred innocent
non-combattants,
they didn't bomb Nanking,
for which no doubt we have
the Brussels
conference
to thank.
Mr. Peck and I had dinner with some
old friends,
and Mrs. Pan of the Ministry of Railways.
It was inter-
first hand of the marvelous job the railroads are doing -
the trains moving under almost impossible odds.
In one instance
over 1000 bombs of
various sizes
were dropped
short stretch of
track but within
twelve hours trains were
again operating over that stretch
of roadbed.
The repair
crews work at night
and sleep in dugouts during
the day
At Soochow they had
an average of eight hours of bombing
for ten
conescutive days,
but still kept the trains
If that sort
can pervade all
services, the Japs are going to have a long and
tough job
ahead.
day - no bomb
raids.
Chinese are asking bids
on 60 basic trainer
airplanes - they must
meeting was
Bond can't get back to Nanking by car because
roads are blocked.
He wired that he was coming by British boat and
driving
car around
the boom in the Yangtsze.
He expects to arrive
Friday or
Will probably wait until he
comes as the
take lcaves tomorrow morning and there probably
will not be another
until the one he comes on.
probably a paint salesman - sold the Chinese
idea of
their buildings a dirty gray coior - supposedly so
so conspicuous from the air.
is done
but nearly
building is covered with that awful looking stuff -
Ming Tomb Memorial and the Mingxians Sun Yat Sen Memorial.
Don't know
Japs overlooked that Memorial and the Ming
though outside the
wall, neither of these "military objectives" have been
bombed.
I predict they will be, and when a howl is raised,
say that anti-aircraft guns were
there.
Of course,
the Japs will
the Chinese
very careful not to give the Japanese any valid reason for bombing the tomb
of their George
Washington.
Dined tonight with some of the American teachers at Nanking
University and some missionaries.
It was easy
to tell which were which -
most of the teachers took a cocktail and smoked.
The missionaries may
do both - like a debutante raiding the ice-box when she gets home - but
with the Ambassador and Mr.Peck both present, they were on their best
behavior and wore the proper funereal
Wednesday,
November 10th.
As I write this I am waiting for a meeting
of the Board of Directors of CNAC - the meeting was called for 3 o'clock
the meeting
not be held until 4.
to call
me
up.
At noon we had an air radd - the first alarm came at 12:20 -
-8-
N 8801 SIPJOS
